channel.title: This but not this
channel.description:
Alright, so, let's say I have "j". J represents id number. I want to set an object with the id of 1911 to be the same as 10000. Is there way to set it so that all the things that 1911 have are the same as 10000. So, basically what I'm saying is. j equals 10000 which equals 1911 BUT 1911 doesn't equal 10000.
Thanks, I can explain more if necessary.

item.title: This but not this
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

Lothy:

May I ask what this is for? Perhaps placing it in some sort of context might give us enough usable information to adequately answer your question (unless Mopar’s code will help you solve your problem).

It would still be nice to know.

Read full topic

item.title: This but not this
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:11, topic:309811”]i think he wants something like:
i %= 1000;
so that i will wrap back around; i = 1001, i %= 1000, i = 1… he just failed to ask correctly?[/quote]

Either that or he meant literally just some numbers equaled other numbers, who knows?

public class StrangeInt {

     private int i;

     public StrangeInt(int i){
          this.i = i;
     }

     public boolean equals(Object other) {
          if (this == other) return true;
          if (!(other instanceof StrangeInt)) return false;

          StrangeInt si = (StrangeInt)other;
          
          return (this.i == si.i) || ( (this.i == 1911) && (si.i == 100000) ) || ( (si.i == 1911) && (this.i == 100000) );
     }

}

What that class does, is do a normal integer to integer comparison on the two values, with the exception of 1911 and 100000 which also equal each other. You should be able to extend the general idea to whatever you want.

Read full topic

item.title: This but not this
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

Right, lemme try rephrase his question.
J is a number. He wants J to be 1199, yet he wants it to be 10000 at the same time. Anything with the id of 1199 would also equal 10000, but all 10000s would not equal 1199.

Read full topic

item.title: This but not this
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Your request doesn’t make the least bit of sense. Do you mean that you want two references to point to the same instance of an object?

Example:
Object a = new Object();
Object b = a;

Note that, in this example, any mutation made to the object referenced by identifier a will be reflected when using the identifier b to access that same object (until one or both of the references have a new value assigned to them).
This doesn’t hold true for primitive types.

All of the above aside, you aren’t making any sense at all. I’m not surprised that you’ve received very little feedback despite the popularity of this forum section.
Perhaps you should reconsider your question.

Read full topic

item.title: This but not this
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

What the fuck are you on about :S.

Now just explain properly what you want to achieve with normal names, that way people might be able to help you
This way you are making no sense to me

item.title: This but not this
item.dc:creator: @cocoa cocoa
item.description:
@cocoa wrote:

[quote=“qauters, post:4, topic:309811”]Class obj_1911
{
}

Class obj_10000 extends obj_1911
{
}

Something like this you mean? obj_10000 is instance of obj_1911 but obj_1911 does not have to be an instance of obj_10000.
Anything added to obj_1911 will also be in obj_10000 etc.

Although you have to use proper names, cause I bet multiple id’s represent the same kind of objects etc.

But yea, explaining it more could make it clear ;)[/quote]

I’m not making a whole new class out of it. lol

I want to set something so that a nonexistant variable will become the same as an already existing one. The reason I said I didn’t want 1911 to equal is because I didn’t want it to be nonexistant.

Read full topic

item.title: This but not this
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:5, topic:309811”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=406252.msg3002451#msg3002451 date=1256108341]
Not without breaking the general contract of the equals(Object) method. =\ What you want to do is break symmetry (and, in turn, transitivity too).

Whatever you’re trying to achieve, you aren’t doing it properly.
[/quote]

this[/quote]but not this
